The x-ray shows an active pulmonary tuberculosis, and the most appropriate next step in management is to administer isoniazid for 9 months, as this is the standard first-line treatment for active tuberculosis. Interferon-γ release assay is used to diagnose tuberculosis, but it is not needed in this case as the diagnosis has already been made. The combination of isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol is used for initial treatment in patients with advanced or severe disease, or in cases where drug resistance is suspected. A chest CT scan may be ordered if there are concerns about disease progression or complications, but it is not the most appropriate next step in this case.

We refer to visual aids on medicine for help. The X-ray shows a solitary pulmonary nodule, which is a common finding on chest X-rays. The next step would be to perform a tuberculosis screening test, such as a Mantoux test or an interferon-γ release assay. However, in this case, the most appropriate next step would be to administer isoniazid for 9 months as the nodule is calcified, which is a sign of old or latent tuberculosis infection. Administering a combination of isoniazid + rifampin + pyrazinamide + ethambutol would be excessive and not indicated in this situation. Obtaining a CT scan would not change the management plan for a calcified nodule.

A positive chest x-ray for tuberculosis (TB) requires further evaluation and treatment. The most appropriate next step in management depends on the patient's risk factors and clinical presentation. In this case, option B, administering isoniazid for 9 months, is the most appropriate choice for latent TB infection in a patient without active symptoms or risk factors. Option A, performing an interferon-gamma release assay, may be used to diagnose TB infection but is not necessary in this case since the patient already has a positive chest x-ray. Option C, administering combination therapy, is used for active TB infection and is not appropriate in this scenario. Option D, obtaining a chest CT scan, may be useful in assessing the extent of disease but is not necessary for initial management of TB infection.

Option C is not recommended as a first-line treatment for latent tuberculosis. A chest CT scan is not necessary at this time.

A chest x-ray is often used as a screening tool for tuberculosis (TB). If the x-ray suggests TB, the next step is to perform a sputum test for acid-fast bacilli (AFB) and either a tuberculin skin test or an interferon-γ release assay (IGRA). Based on the results, the patient may be treated with isoniazid for 9 months or with other drugs such as rifampin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol.
